Text: Not to us, O LORD, not to us, but to Your name be the glory, because of Your loving devotion, because of Your faithfulness.
Context: The psalmist is expressing a fundamental tenet of humility and the priority of God’s glory over human recognition.

Text: Why should the nations say, “Where is their God?”
Context: The rhetorical question reflects the taunting of other nations, questioning the presence or power of the Israelites' God.

Text: Our God is in heaven and does whatever pleases Him.
Context: Affirming the sovereign authority of God, contrasting the true God with idols.

Text: Their idols are silver and gold, made by the hands of men.
Context: The text critiques the worthlessness of idols made by human hands.

Text: They have mouths but cannot speak, eyes but cannot see.
Context: Describing the impotence of idols, emphasizing their inability to act or perceive.

Text: They have ears but cannot hear, noses but cannot smell.
Context: Continuing the description of the ineffectiveness of idols, highlighting their lifelessness.

Text: They have hands but cannot feel, feet but cannot walk; they cannot make a sound with their throats.
Context: Further illustrating the helplessness of idols, noting their total lack of power or vitality.

Text: Those who make them will become like them, along with all who trust in them.
Context: Warning of the spiritual danger in idolatry, implying that idolaters will become as ineffective as the idols they worship.

Text: O Israel, trust in the LORD; He is their help and shield.
Context: A call to trust in the LORD rather than idols, reinforced by the assurance of God's protection.

Text: O house of Aaron, trust in the LORD; He is their help and shield.
Context: Extending the call to trust to the priestly class, again pointing to the LORD’s protective nature.

Text: You who fear the LORD, trust in the LORD; He is their help and shield.
Context: Encouraging all God-fearers to trust in the LORD, emphasizing God's role as protector.

Text: The LORD has been mindful of us; He will bless us; He will bless the house of Israel; He will bless the house of Aaron;
Context: Expressing gratitude for God’s attentiveness and the blessings bestowed upon Israel and its priests.

Text: He will bless those who fear the LORD, both small and great.
Context: Stating that God’s blessings are not limited by social status, inclusive of all who fear Him.

Text: May the LORD give you increase, you and your children.
Context: Expressing a prayerful wish for prosperity and blessing on the people and their offspring.

Text: May you be blessed by the LORD, the Maker of heaven and earth.
Context: Blessing the people in the name of the LORD, the Creator of all.

Text: The highest heavens belong to the LORD, but the earth He has given to mankind.
Context: Acknowledging God’s supreme ownership of creation, yet God’s gracious gift of the earth to humanity.

Text: It is not the dead who praise the LORD, nor any of those descending into silence.
Context: A sobering truth that praises for God come from the living, not the dead.

Text: But we will bless the LORD from this time forth and forevermore. Praise the LORD!
Context: Committing to continuous praise of the LORD, culminating in a call for others to join in praise.
